So we're going to focus primarily on growing our service-sensitive business and reflecting the long-term value of that business with our pricing. And we've been able to achieve 5 consecutive quarters of RPU growth ex fuel, and we believe that will continue.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And my follow-up question. Thinking about the $420 million of savings on the labor line, what are the specific headcount expectations that are embedded within that? And could you give us a sense of what you're thinking about that -- what that
componenttext: Okay, great. And my follow-up question. Thinking about the $420 million of savings on the labor line, what are the specific headcount expectations that are embedded within that? And could you give us a sense of what you're thinking about that -- what that might imply from a GTM per employee or a carload per employee perspective?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, again, I'll turn it over to Mike to talk about the specifics on the headcount. But we're looking for roughly 2,000 fewer positions by 2020 and 1,200 fewer positions and about a 4% decrease in our overall workforce in 2016. So Mike, do you want
componenttext: Sure. Well, again, I'll turn it over to Mike to talk about the specifics on the headcount. But we're looking for roughly 2,000 fewer positions by 2020 and 1,200 fewer positions and about a 4% decrease in our overall workforce in 2016. So Mike, do you want to get into the specifics there a little bit?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it is driven by the 2,000 headcount reduction by 2020 as well as aggressive overtime reduction by 2020, and we've already started that in 2016 and seen some good headways. And as we've said, that's about a 4% reduction for this year in our headcou
componenttext: Yes. So it is driven by the 2,000 headcount reduction by 2020 as well as aggressive overtime reduction by 2020, and we've already started that in 2016 and seen some good headways. And as we've said, that's about a 4% reduction for this year in our headcount, and we would expect that to translate directly into the gross ton-miles per revenue.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Vecchio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Vecchio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jim, I realized the forecast for coal to decline at a 1% CAGR is more conservative than some other estimates out there, but naturally, a 1% decline over the next 5 years would suggest that the mix headwind from coal declines from a profitability standp
componenttext: So Jim, I realized the forecast for coal to decline at a 1% CAGR is more conservative than some other estimates out there, but naturally, a 1% decline over the next 5 years would suggest that the mix headwind from coal declines from a profitability standpoint would moderate pretty drastically versus what you've experienced over the last few years. So my question is, if coal volumes do end up declining kind of closer to the mid- to high single digits, as they have been over the past few years, do still believe you'll be able to achieve your OR and EPS targets?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I'd like to do is turn it over to Alan in a minute to give you some of the detail on how we built up the coal volume forecast, which, as you point out, we do believe is conservative based on independent experts. But let me just say this about our pla
componenttext: What I'd like to do is turn it over to Alan in a minute to give you some of the detail on how we built up the coal volume forecast, which, as you point out, we do believe is conservative based on independent experts. But let me just say this about our plan. It is a dynamic, flexible plan. If we do not see the growth in revenue because our coal volumes trend worse than we are -- expected or for whatever reason, we will push even harder on the cost side. It's a flexible plan. We can dig deeper on the cost if we have to. We are intent on achieving the results we have outlined today.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, we know that coal volume will decline in 2016. And that's reflected in most indices. And then what we've done is we have looked at our individual plants, our individual customers; and then anchored that against independent experts. And we have come
componenttext: Alex, we know that coal volume will decline in 2016. And that's reflected in most indices. And then what we've done is we have looked at our individual plants, our individual customers; and then anchored that against independent experts. And we have come up with what we believe is a conservative plan going forward. Yes, there's risk. There's no doubt about it, but at price -- gas prices levels where they are today, coal-to-gas switching in our service region is effectively saturated. And so we do feel good about our coal forecast going forward. It's more conservative than outside experts, but we will adjust accordingly if we see the market dynamics change.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then my follow-up. So you've given a lot more detailed guidance, which is great. And you've spoken a bit more specifically to your expectations for core pricing. I was wondering if maybe you'd be willing to begin disclosing more
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then my follow-up. So you've given a lot more detailed guidance, which is great. And you've spoken a bit more specifically to your expectations for core pricing. I was wondering if maybe you'd be willing to begin disclosing more specifically your same-store-sale core pricing metrics on a quarterly basis, as other Class 1s have been doing; and maybe if you could provide what that figure was in the fourth quarter.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Listen, let me just say this. With the leadership transition here, everything is on the table. And we are certainly considering changes in a variety of areas, including our disclosure policy. Alan, do you want to comment on the same-store sales numb
componenttext: Sure. Listen, let me just say this. With the leadership transition here, everything is on the table. And we are certainly considering changes in a variety of areas, including our disclosure policy. Alan, do you want to comment on the same-store sales number in the fourth quarter?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was above rail inflation. And we're going to continue to get improvement in that as we realize the full year benefit of the contract rate increases that we negotiated with our customers this year. Also, with a sharply declined fuel surcharge overhang,
componenttext: It was above rail inflation. And we're going to continue to get improvement in that as we realize the full year benefit of the contract rate increases that we negotiated with our customers this year. Also, with a sharply declined fuel surcharge overhang, we'll see better improvement in RPU throughout the year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to see if you could give me, this is probably for Mike or Jim, what, broadly speaking, are some of your assumptions on train lengths and train starts over the 5-year period. I guess, typically, we think of train starts as driving costs and headcoun
componenttext: Wanted to see if you could give me, this is probably for Mike or Jim, what, broadly speaking, are some of your assumptions on train lengths and train starts over the 5-year period. I guess, typically, we think of train starts as driving costs and headcount. And likewise, what you do on train lengths, that's been an area that you can drive productivity, so are there any kind of broad thoughts you can provide on how you think those 2 parameters may move over the 5-year period?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, train lengths are obviously an important driver of productivity. And fewer starts for trains is also an important driver. Now Mike, why don't you talk a little bit about specifics there?
componenttext: Well, first, train lengths are obviously an important driver of productivity. And fewer starts for trains is also an important driver. Now Mike, why don't you talk a little bit about specifics there?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on our train lengths, this last quarter as well as last year, our train lengths were at our historic highs. And they were at our historic highs at the same time that our service levels were at their historic highs. So we feel pretty good about tha
componenttext: Yes. So on our train lengths, this last quarter as well as last year, our train lengths were at our historic highs. And they were at our historic highs at the same time that our service levels were at their historic highs. So we feel pretty good about that going forward. Now having said that, we continue to tactically look at what are the opportunities to run longer trains, and we do that daily. We've got a team looking at that intensely. And we also -- looking at, strategically, long-term looking at longer trains. And what we're doing there is reviewing our operating plan, and we continue to fine-tune it to optimize the operating plan. And it will allow us to not only run longer trains but reduce our car miles and reduce handlings, and those go hand-in-hand with increased efficiency. So we -- while we feel like we're in a good place, we do see opportunity going forward.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, maybe I should ask it a little bit differently. Is -- do you have specific targets for change in train length that are part of the broader productivity plan? Is there -- are you planning to improve it 10%, 20%? Or is that not one of the key driver
componenttext: I mean, maybe I should ask it a little bit differently. Is -- do you have specific targets for change in train length that are part of the broader productivity plan? Is there -- are you planning to improve it 10%, 20%? Or is that not one of the key drivers in your 5-year plan?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's not one of the ones that we put a specific metric on. We plan to improve it, but we don't have a target for that.
componenttext: No, it's not one of the ones that we put a specific metric on. We plan to improve it, but we don't have a target for that.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I don't know if I can get kind of a follow-on or a different topic, but is there any implication for long-term CapEx within the structural changes? If you take out 1,500 miles of track, does that help you get a lower CapEx number in the lon
componenttext: Okay. And then I don't know if I can get kind of a follow-on or a different topic, but is there any implication for long-term CapEx within the structural changes? If you take out 1,500 miles of track, does that help you get a lower CapEx number in the longer term?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It does, it does. And that's one of the benefits of reducing the network footprint from the 1,000 miles of rationalization we're looking at this year and fully 1,500 miles by 2020. That does bring your CapEx down with respect to those lines, and there are
componenttext: It does, it does. And that's one of the benefits of reducing the network footprint from the 1,000 miles of rationalization we're looking at this year and fully 1,500 miles by 2020. That does bring your CapEx down with respect to those lines, and there are some expense benefit from that as well. And we are also looking at trying to contain CapEx at a lower level overall than it has been at in the last several years. We pointed out, again, that we reduced CapEx last year. That was appropriate given the circumstances. This year's capital budget starting out is double digits lower than last year's. And we'll continue to be flexible with CapEx as market conditions require.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Group with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Group with Wolfe Research.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So wanted to follow up on the headcount. Because you're -- I guess you're talking about a 7% reduction in headcount from here. Now it strikes me, though, that volumes were down 7% in the fourth quarter and your headcount was up 2%. And meanwhile, like all
componenttext: So wanted to follow up on the headcount. Because you're -- I guess you're talking about a 7% reduction in headcount from here. Now it strikes me, though, that volumes were down 7% in the fourth quarter and your headcount was up 2%. And meanwhile, like all the other rails had headcount reductions in that 7% range. So if your, like, 7% headcount reduction is kind of just a catch-up to what other rails have just done to respond to the weak volumes and if we're thinking about like real productivity savings, why isn't there, like, a lot more headcount potential here? Because that's where we can get the most confidence and visibility to real margin improvement, and it feels like there should be potential for a lot more. And I guess I'm just not sure why we can't see that.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, first, let me just -- we started at a lower level of headcount overall. We've built headcount somewhat last year to get our service back up to where it needs to be. It's there, and now we can begin to modulate headcount down. 1,200 fewer
componenttext: All right. Well, first, let me just -- we started at a lower level of headcount overall. We've built headcount somewhat last year to get our service back up to where it needs to be. It's there, and now we can begin to modulate headcount down. 1,200 fewer employees through a combination of attrition and furloughs this year would represent a 4% reduction in our workforce overall year-over-year. We've given you the cost savings we expect from the attrition and the furloughs and other actions on comp and benefits. That's a big piece of the overall $650 million in productivity, annualized by 2020, fully $420 million.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the cash flow just for a minute. When do you think you can get back to kind of the historical 16%, 17% of revenue on CapEx? I guess a follow-up to what Tom was just asking. And then, Marta, any thoughts on why you're slowing the buy
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the cash flow just for a minute. When do you think you can get back to kind of the historical 16%, 17% of revenue on CapEx? I guess a follow-up to what Tom was just asking. And then, Marta, any thoughts on why you're slowing the buybacks in '16?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's talk about CapEx first, and I'll let Marta cover buybacks second. We're targeting about 19% of revenue through the completion of PTC, which takes us through 2018. After that, we intend to bring CapEx down to around 17%. We think that's a level of re
componenttext: Let's talk about CapEx first, and I'll let Marta cover buybacks second. We're targeting about 19% of revenue through the completion of PTC, which takes us through 2018. After that, we intend to bring CapEx down to around 17%. We think that's a level of reinvestment, given other assumptions, that generates an adequate return for shareholders, an excellent return for shareholders, in fact. Marta, why don't you talk about the buyback strategy?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. In the share repurchases, we discussed we're beginning at a run rate this quarter of $200 million, which would imply, right now, $800 million for the year, and that's very much in line with what we've done over the last 10 years. We've averaged abou
componenttext: Okay. In the share repurchases, we discussed we're beginning at a run rate this quarter of $200 million, which would imply, right now, $800 million for the year, and that's very much in line with what we've done over the last 10 years. We've averaged about $1 billion. So in some years, a little bit higher; some years, a little bit lower. We finished 2015 at $1.1 billion. So we're comfortable with that level of guidance for now.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I do want to point out, Scott, our board is very focused on buybacks right now. That's a big part of our strategy. It has been in the past. As we went through, we have kicked out to shareholders fully $15 billion through buybacks and dividends in the
componenttext: And I do want to point out, Scott, our board is very focused on buybacks right now. That's a big part of our strategy. It has been in the past. As we went through, we have kicked out to shareholders fully $15 billion through buybacks and dividends in the past, and we will continue to buy back our shares.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Barnes with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Barnes with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to coal for a second because I think we're struggling a little bit with the numbers in terms of kind of the growth outlook. I mean, if I assume that '16 is going to be down something similar to what the other rails are talking about
componenttext: I just want to go back to coal for a second because I think we're struggling a little bit with the numbers in terms of kind of the growth outlook. I mean, if I assume that '16 is going to be down something similar to what the other rails are talking about, let's say, it's a mid-teens type of decline this year, regardless of whether or not your franchise is less at risk to more switching on natural gas or something like that, you're still implying something like mid-single-digit compounded annual growth from like 2017 through 2020. And I just -- I think that when you look at the change in the Eastern Utilities portfolio, whether it's the introduction of more nuclear or what have you, that just seems like a big number, a big target out there for growth, I mean. And certainly, that's a growth number, not stabilization. So can you just talk a little bit more about how you start to see that upswing and where this kind of CAGR of down 1% kind of fits with something that looks like it's more up mid-single-digit in the out-years?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not looking for growth in coal in the out-years. So 2016 is another leg down in coal volumes, and after that, we see stabilization of the coal volumes. And I'll let Alan return to the specific assumptions that underlie that, but let me just reemphas
componenttext: We're not looking for growth in coal in the out-years. So 2016 is another leg down in coal volumes, and after that, we see stabilization of the coal volumes. And I'll let Alan return to the specific assumptions that underlie that, but let me just reemphasize. So ours is a flexible plan. We know this is a tough environment in which to talk about growth, and that's why we are so focused on cost reductions, on maintaining excellent service and on safety. If we do those 3 things, we will have a successful 2016. And we will continue to drive on those 3 things as hard as we possibly can beyond 2016, and we expect the results to offset any decline in volumes or revenue that we might experience contrary to our expectations.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We know that much of the coal decline this year is the result of the warm weather, and with coal dispatching by nat -- behind natural gas, it is much more volatile with weather conditions. We're very clear that our guidance, once stockpiles normalize
componenttext: Yes. We know that much of the coal decline this year is the result of the warm weather, and with coal dispatching by nat -- behind natural gas, it is much more volatile with weather conditions. We're very clear that our guidance, once stockpiles normalize, is dependent upon normal weather patterns. We also know that the opportunity for coal-to-gas switching in our specific service region and particularly in the Southeast is muted going forward. But to be clear, we are not looking for growth in our coal franchise. We expect it to decline. We're going to manage it very closely and continue to manage the resources that are applied to it -- against it.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what assumptions have you made for coal shutdowns within the franchise in that forecasted amount?
componenttext: And what assumptions have you made for coal shutdowns within the franchise in that forecasted amount?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- most of the additional natural gas plants that have been announced in the Southeast are not targeted at specific NS plants. Up in the PJM, there is more crossover and there's more risk, and we've taken that into account. There is a specific plan in
componenttext: The -- most of the additional natural gas plants that have been announced in the Southeast are not targeted at specific NS plants. Up in the PJM, there is more crossover and there's more risk, and we've taken that into account. There is a specific plan in the Southeast that's been taken into account in our franchise, too. So it comes in conjunction with looking at the announced natural gas plant additions in the next couple of years and talking to our customers about it. So we do have some of it in there, more predominant in the Northeast.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And then my follow-up question -- my follow-up is, you talked about 1,500 miles of track disposal. I know you guys sell real estate every year, so you kind of know how to do it. But my question on track disposal going forward is, it seems
componenttext: Okay, all right. And then my follow-up question -- my follow-up is, you talked about 1,500 miles of track disposal. I know you guys sell real estate every year, so you kind of know how to do it. But my question on track disposal going forward is, it seems like a lot of this is going to be stuff that maybe doesn't have a lot of value left in -- to a short-line rail, there's not enough volume originating on that particular track. So I'm curious, I mean, should we expect lower proceeds from track sales going forward just because there's less value on them? I mean, are these going to be turned into really nice bike paths or something like that? Or is there still some value to be had to the short line? Is there still enough volume originating on that 1,500 miles if there's some value there?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the way to view this, John, is not as a real estate transaction or a real estate strategy but as a network optimization strategy, and it's a mechanism by which we can bring down future capital spending associated with these lines, as we had said a
componenttext: I think the way to view this, John, is not as a real estate transaction or a real estate strategy but as a network optimization strategy, and it's a mechanism by which we can bring down future capital spending associated with these lines, as we had said and also, to some extent, reduce expenses. And Alan, do you want to elaborate at all on the customer effects of some of this -- the short line potential? Some of this may be dealt to short lines.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some of it will be dealt to short lines so we can continue to handle the business. And the ultimate goal is to ensure that, with the short line handling, we do not increase the cost to the supply chain.
componenttext: Some of it will be dealt to short lines so we can continue to handle the business. And the ultimate goal is to ensure that, with the short line handling, we do not increase the cost to the supply chain.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citi.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to touch on sort of the broad volume outlook for 2016. So understanding sort of where you guys are thinking about coal, but when you think about the entire book of business, how should we think about that in 2016? It sounds like first quarter is
componenttext: I wanted to touch on sort of the broad volume outlook for 2016. So understanding sort of where you guys are thinking about coal, but when you think about the entire book of business, how should we think about that in 2016? It sounds like first quarter is going to be tougher, but how does it look after that?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, it remains a challenging macro environment. Alan will go through the specific assumptions for 2016. But again, let me say this is why we are so focused on cost savings, on maintaining service and on safety. Those will be the 3 pillars of our su
componenttext: Certainly, it remains a challenging macro environment. Alan will go through the specific assumptions for 2016. But again, let me say this is why we are so focused on cost savings, on maintaining service and on safety. Those will be the 3 pillars of our success in 2016. The growth will come. This is a long-range plan, and over the course of 5 years, we do expect growth. And we all know how powerful growth and pricing can be for the bottom line in the long run.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The largest headwinds that we have right now with respect to near-term volume are coal inventory levels and retail inventory levels. Once those get worked through, we do see some growth because we're coming off a year in which we had minimal growth. We ha
componenttext: The largest headwinds that we have right now with respect to near-term volume are coal inventory levels and retail inventory levels. Once those get worked through, we do see some growth because we're coming off a year in which we had minimal growth. We have a very strong intermodal franchise. Our proved [ph] service product is going to direct more of that business back to our lines in our -- the domestic sector as we move into the second half of the year. We have a lot of strength in our international franchise, and once retail inventory levels are normalized, that'll pick up. And we have strengthen in our automotive franchise. So we do have some franchises that have opportunities for growth. We had a record volume in chemicals last year, and we had record volume in intermodal, too, despite the Triple Crown restructuring. Also note that Triple Crown will have a negative impact on volume comps, particularly for the first 3 quarters of the year. But we do feel that as we progress through the year and as we take advantage of our service product and as inventory levels, whether in retail or in coal, normalize, we're going to start to see significant improvement.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But you're not predicating the outlook for '16 on volume growth, it sounds like, though.
componenttext: Okay. But you're not predicating the outlook for '16 on volume growth, it sounds like, though.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. There is certainly opportunity there, but we're watching it very closely because there's a lot of uncertainty around commodities and a lot of uncertainty on when particularly the retail inventory levels get reversed. We're actively managing it with op
componenttext: No. There is certainly opportunity there, but we're watching it very closely because there's a lot of uncertainty around commodities and a lot of uncertainty on when particularly the retail inventory levels get reversed. We're actively managing it with operations to make sure we're sizing our resources appropriately.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And just a quick follow-up, if I may, just on the fuel surcharge side. Marta, thanks for the incremental -- the details that you've been giving us in terms of fuel surcharge. As you see the WTI program sort of bottom out here in Januar
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And just a quick follow-up, if I may, just on the fuel surcharge side. Marta, thanks for the incremental -- the details that you've been giving us in terms of fuel surcharge. As you see the WTI program sort of bottom out here in January and then going forward, how should we think about the headwind to operating profit? You've sort of laid that out in the slide. Just kind of curious if there's a view that you can give us for 2016 when you think about that sort of what's included in terms of either headwind or sort of neutral impact from the fuel surcharge to profit in 2016.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So as Alan described, in the first quarter, that's the -- the first quarter is the one that will have the toughest comp compared to 2015 because recall that the first quarter of 2015, in January, some of those WTI ones were kicking in. So we had $16
componenttext: Okay. So as Alan described, in the first quarter, that's the -- the first quarter is the one that will have the toughest comp compared to 2015 because recall that the first quarter of 2015, in January, some of those WTI ones were kicking in. So we had $163 million of fuel surcharge in the first quarter of '15. So year-over-year, the biggest decline that we will see -- we expect, if the forward curve stays like it is now, will be in the first quarter. Nevertheless, for the -- for all of the year, for all of the quarters, we expect to have much less net operating profit effect because our fuel expenses will be going down more commensurately with our fuel revenue, if we stay in this oil price environment.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jim, I know you said at the outset that you don't really want to talk about CP, but I'm getting plenty of e-mails here from investors that would like to discuss it. So I guess, in that context, I just want to respectfully ask. We've heard from these pl
componenttext: So Jim, I know you said at the outset that you don't really want to talk about CP, but I'm getting plenty of e-mails here from investors that would like to discuss it. So I guess, in that context, I just want to respectfully ask. We've heard from these plans from Norfolk over the years that you guys always target peer margins, but we now have Canadian National, Canadian Pacific, Union Pacific all in the low 60s even cleaned up for the currency benefits of North. And we're still struggling with the coal guidance. I think there was a question earlier about how do you get to a negative 1% CAGR when you're guiding 15% down this year. Clearly, 4Q was pretty challenging here even after you take out the restructuring charges, and I don't think that we would argue that any of those big railroads that are running at a low 60s OR right now are in some sort of unsustainable or less safe operating conditions than they were when they were running back in the 80s or even 90s OR. So with your plan to drive about $600 million to $650 million of productivity improvements in the next 5 years and CP's plan, which, I would argue, is backed up by a management team that's demonstrated the ability to do this in a very quick fashion, I think CP's plan is close to $1.2 billion over the same time frame. So what is it about your business that you feel CP does not understand that makes shareholders better off with $650 million of improvement versus a low 60s OR and a $1.2 billion improvement plan?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've outlined a plan today to get to a sub-65 operating ratio by 2020, and as I said, we won't stop there. There's more we can do. We are going to continue to drive our operating ratio as low as we possibly can go with it. It's a good plan. It's a bal
componenttext: So we've outlined a plan today to get to a sub-65 operating ratio by 2020, and as I said, we won't stop there. There's more we can do. We are going to continue to drive our operating ratio as low as we possibly can go with it. It's a good plan. It's a balanced plan. It contains a major component of cost cutting, and we understand the need for that. That's absolutely critical. It's a flexible plan. If we don't see the growth, we will find additional ways to reduce expenses. It's a specific plan. It's the right plan for our markets, our franchise and our customers.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as a follow-up then, so are you saying that $1.2 billion of improvement is just nowhere near attainable in the time frame that they've laid out? Can Norfolk ever get to a 60% operating ratio? Or is that just off the table for your network?
componenttext: Well, as a follow-up then, so are you saying that $1.2 billion of improvement is just nowhere near attainable in the time frame that they've laid out? Can Norfolk ever get to a 60% operating ratio? Or is that just off the table for your network?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said, 65% is the starting point for us. That's what we've said we're going to try to achieve by 2020. We may be able to go faster, we'll see. After we reach 65%, we're going to continue to drive it lower.
componenttext: As I said, 65% is the starting point for us. That's what we've said we're going to try to achieve by 2020. We may be able to go faster, we'll see. After we reach 65%, we're going to continue to drive it lower.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Troy with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Troy with Nomura.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could help us with the economics of the Pocahontas division now that it's being consolidated. Just curious if you could size the magnitude of the royalties, will your disclosure change with respect to how it's presented and how
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could help us with the economics of the Pocahontas division now that it's being consolidated. Just curious if you could size the magnitude of the royalties, will your disclosure change with respect to how it's presented and how much of a headwind that might be and the timing of headwind as it runs off.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, Matt, we're talking about 2 different things here. The division consolidation that Mike went through reflects a strategy to reduce G&A, streamline operations and streamline the organization. The coal royalties you referenced appear in our othe
componenttext: So I think, Matt, we're talking about 2 different things here. The division consolidation that Mike went through reflects a strategy to reduce G&A, streamline operations and streamline the organization. The coal royalties you referenced appear in our other income as part of rental and other income. Marta, maybe you could give us a run rate on that.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you've mentioned, those have been decreasing, of course, with decline in coal prices. So Matt, that will continue to be reported in other income. And depending on prices -- and depending on coal prices, that will continue -- perhaps continue to de
componenttext: Yes. As you've mentioned, those have been decreasing, of course, with decline in coal prices. So Matt, that will continue to be reported in other income. And depending on prices -- and depending on coal prices, that will continue -- perhaps continue to decline. So that's reflected in our charts, in our book that we put out, and they were down $4 million in the fourth quarter and $14 million for the full year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But the divisional reorganization in and of itself has no effect on...
componenttext: But the divisional reorganization in and of itself has no effect on...

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I am glad you asked that question because with both of them having a corporation that handles the coal royalties being called Pocahontas and the division being called Pocahontas, we don't want any confusion there.
componenttext: But I am glad you asked that question because with both of them having a corporation that handles the coal royalties being called Pocahontas and the division being called Pocahontas, we don't want any confusion there.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then just as my follow-up, you mentioned share repurchases as big part of your plan, and you gave us a targeted payout ratio of 33% and the return of $15 billion to shareholders. Just curious, maybe Marta, what are the guardrails in terms
componenttext: Understood. And then just as my follow-up, you mentioned share repurchases as big part of your plan, and you gave us a targeted payout ratio of 33% and the return of $15 billion to shareholders. Just curious, maybe Marta, what are the guardrails in terms of balance sheet leverage or capital structure with respect to credit rating or leverage ratios you're comfortable pushing up against in order to drive share repurchases over time? Just want to refresh on where you think Norfolk is comfortable with respect to some of those credit metrics.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, as you know, share repurchase is just one part of our total capital allocation policy. It is a very important part, as Jim mentioned. Our board is very focused on it. What we are doing is we are making sure that we stay within our credit ratin
componenttext: Okay. Well, as you know, share repurchase is just one part of our total capital allocation policy. It is a very important part, as Jim mentioned. Our board is very focused on it. What we are doing is we are making sure that we stay within our credit ratings band, but we want to make sure we leverage as much as we can on that. And that's what we have done, buying back a little over $1 billion a year on average over the last 10 years. So right now, our expectation is that we will stay within that band and push as much of our free cash flow into share repurchases, combined with the appropriate amount of leverage.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But just trying to get specifically as we think about modeling. You are willing to lever up more than where you are today? Is there an upper band that you think you can take that...
componenttext: But just trying to get specifically as we think about modeling. You are willing to lever up more than where you are today? Is there an upper band that you think you can take that...

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As our balance sheet grows and as our profits grow with this 5-year plan that Jim has described, we expect to grow our share repurchase program with it.
componenttext: As our balance sheet grows and as our profits grow with this 5-year plan that Jim has described, we expect to grow our share repurchase program with it.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Salmon with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Salmon with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Jim, as a clarification for your 2016 OR guidance. You guys highlighted a bunch of track mile sales as well as Roanoke office, I would imagine, is also going to be sold. Should we be contemplating that there's some -- could you clarify it to the
componenttext: I guess, Jim, as a clarification for your 2016 OR guidance. You guys highlighted a bunch of track mile sales as well as Roanoke office, I would imagine, is also going to be sold. Should we be contemplating that there's some -- could you clarify it to the extent that gains are incorporated in that sub-70 OR guidance that you're targeting for the full year? Because obviously, it's a tough volume backdrop and there'll be some mix headwinds as well as we look out to this year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So speaking specifically to real estate sales. Gain on real estate sales, including any gain we record on sale of the Roanoke office building, would not be included in operating income but would be below the operating income line, in other income. So that
componenttext: So speaking specifically to real estate sales. Gain on real estate sales, including any gain we record on sale of the Roanoke office building, would not be included in operating income but would be below the operating income line, in other income. So that would have no impact on the operating ratio. And the proceeds from any line sales, I think, would be rather minimal in conjunction with the restructuring or rationalization of the 1,000 miles we referred to. There could be some proceeds from that, but again, the main focus of that is reduction in capital spending and, to some extent, expenses going forward.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, and I appreciate that clarification there. I guess getting back to Tom's earlier question with regard to sidings. I'm going to ask it a little bit differently. Could you give us a sense of what the siding capacity is today across your differen
componenttext: Understood, and I appreciate that clarification there. I guess getting back to Tom's earlier question with regard to sidings. I'm going to ask it a little bit differently. Could you give us a sense of what the siding capacity is today across your different franchises and what the train length currently stands at?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Mike?
componenttext: Okay. Mike?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Most of our sidings from the railroad are 8,000 feet long. As we've built new sidings and we've built a lot of new sidings over the years and we've built some up in the 10,000, 11,000, 12,000-foot range, so we've got a lot of siding capacity ou
componenttext: Yes, sure. Most of our sidings from the railroad are 8,000 feet long. As we've built new sidings and we've built a lot of new sidings over the years and we've built some up in the 10,000, 11,000, 12,000-foot range, so we've got a lot of siding capacity out there relative to the size of the trains we're running now. Our intermodal trains are running around 6,000 feet on average. A lot of capacity there. And the rest of the overall network is in the 5,000 to 6,000 feet, so we have got plenty of capacity on our sidings out there.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bascome Majors with Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bascome Majors with Susquehanna.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in framing your targeted expense reductions, I want to confirm that we should use 2015's GAAP results as a baseline and better understand how we should incorporate what are natural volume-driven OpEx fluctuations and general expense inflation to those
componenttext: So in framing your targeted expense reductions, I want to confirm that we should use 2015's GAAP results as a baseline and better understand how we should incorporate what are natural volume-driven OpEx fluctuations and general expense inflation to those numbers going forward. So since volume and sensitive costs should be down in 2016, is your $130 million productivity target for the year, is that fully incremental to the cost savings that you'd naturally see from lower volumes? And maybe longer term, as volumes return to growth per the plan, how should we compare that rise in volume-driven expense and the broader cost inflation you'll see to your longer-term target for $650 million in savings over 5 years?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So first, comparisons are to GAAP results in 2015. So the cost savings that we have outlined are in relation to GAAP reported earnings in 2015. And Marta, why don't you take us through the dynamics of the productivity and other elements of the quest
componenttext: Okay. So first, comparisons are to GAAP results in 2015. So the cost savings that we have outlined are in relation to GAAP reported earnings in 2015. And Marta, why don't you take us through the dynamics of the productivity and other elements of the question?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they are compared to GAAP. The $130 million in savings does not include the benefit of the restructuring cost. So if you're looking year-over-year and you're looking at total expenses, you would expect a decline of $130 million plus the $93 million o
componenttext: Yes, they are compared to GAAP. The $130 million in savings does not include the benefit of the restructuring cost. So if you're looking year-over-year and you're looking at total expenses, you would expect a decline of $130 million plus the $93 million of the restructuring cost that we had. Otherwise, it's all in there, the pluses and the minuses. So I mean, if we have growth -- if we have volume growth, you're exactly right, we would have incremental expenses associated with that volume growth, and that would not be in the $130 million.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And maybe from a high level, just looking at the guidance to get below a 70% OR this year. If I plug the 70% OR into consensus revenues, it looks like something around 10% year-over-year EPS growth on your 2015 GAAP base of about $5.10.
componenttext: Okay, understood. And maybe from a high level, just looking at the guidance to get below a 70% OR this year. If I plug the 70% OR into consensus revenues, it looks like something around 10% year-over-year EPS growth on your 2015 GAAP base of about $5.10. Is that the bogey that we should be looking at? Or is there something underlying, maybe consensus revenue is too high or something else that we should be thinking about before using that as kind of our sense of your internal targets here?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, we said sub 65 -- excuse me, sub-70 operating ratio in 2016 is our goal, and that's what we're working toward through whatever combination of growth or lack thereof or -- and expense savings. If we're heading into a recession, obviously, the degree
componenttext: Look, we said sub 65 -- excuse me, sub-70 operating ratio in 2016 is our goal, and that's what we're working toward through whatever combination of growth or lack thereof or -- and expense savings. If we're heading into a recession, obviously, the degree of difficulty gets that much higher, but we are committed to this goal and we're pushing hard to achieve it.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I will point out too that -- and Alan can elaborate on this, but I will point out too that while we're expecting volume declines in coal, that's not the case for all of our commodity groups.
componenttext: And I will point out too that -- and Alan can elaborate on this, but I will point out too that while we're expecting volume declines in coal, that's not the case for all of our commodity groups.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll pivot if we need to as well. And if we need to pivot harder on costs, we will certainly do that. We're not going to sacrifice our service, but everything else is on the table. We'll cut whatever we need to cut, short of hurting service.
componenttext: We'll pivot if we need to as well. And if we need to pivot harder on costs, we will certainly do that. We're not going to sacrifice our service, but everything else is on the table. We'll cut whatever we need to cut, short of hurting service.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, just a follow-up on that is, if volumes do come in kind of as you expected, is something approaching the double digits on your GAAP earnings base the question for this year? Or is that within the range of possibilities in your view?
componenttext: Well, I guess, just a follow-up on that is, if volumes do come in kind of as you expected, is something approaching the double digits on your GAAP earnings base the question for this year? Or is that within the range of possibilities in your view?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, that's -- you can do the math on the EPS effect of driving the operating ratio below 70%.
componenttext: I mean, that's -- you can do the math on the EPS effect of driving the operating ratio below 70%.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Seidl with Cowen.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Seidl with Cowen.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question has to do with your CapEx going forward. Obviously, with shutting down some of your lines, as you've had with coal, and looking at the shutdown, I think, what'd you say, of 1,500 miles of track, rearranging some of your locomotive needs and
componenttext: First question has to do with your CapEx going forward. Obviously, with shutting down some of your lines, as you've had with coal, and looking at the shutdown, I think, what'd you say, of 1,500 miles of track, rearranging some of your locomotive needs and car types, where is the new mix going to be? Is the mix going to change in terms of what you're investing in as we look in Norfolk Southern in 2020 versus 2015?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you'll see -- well, by 2020, we will be done with PTC. And so you'll see some -- you'll see that roll out. You'll see more focus on core investments in our core network. That will certainly be part of the equation all the way out to 2020. We will co
componenttext: Well, you'll see -- well, by 2020, we will be done with PTC. And so you'll see some -- you'll see that roll out. You'll see more focus on core investments in our core network. That will certainly be part of the equation all the way out to 2020. We will continue to invest in locomotives and equipment and other structures and other critical aspects of infrastructure. So other than the absence of PTC, no major change in the mix of our investments other than perhaps greater concentration on core lines.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's good clarification. And Marta, just to get some clarification for '17 kind of in relation to everyone trying to pinpoint an EPS number for you. You talked about your tax rate dropping down. It sounded like there were several items that hit it
componenttext: Okay. That's good clarification. And Marta, just to get some clarification for '17 kind of in relation to everyone trying to pinpoint an EPS number for you. You talked about your tax rate dropping down. It sounded like there were several items that hit it, but it sounded like some of these items might be continuing into 2016 here. What should we look at in terms of your tax rate for the year?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you are correct about that. The Tax Extenders Act also extended the credits already for this year. So we would expect -- in prior years, we've guided to an effective tax rate of about 37.5%. But for 2016, we think it will be more like 37% even.
componenttext: Yes, you are correct about that. The Tax Extenders Act also extended the credits already for this year. So we would expect -- in prior years, we've guided to an effective tax rate of about 37.5%. But for 2016, we think it will be more like 37% even.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Hoexter with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Hoexter with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we look back at the plan on Page 8, you see a lot of revenue growth. And I just want to understand, in this lower-growth market, you're expecting pricing to scale up to 2.5% from 0 the last few years, your volume growth to accelerate. And I don't know
componenttext: If we look back at the plan on Page 8, you see a lot of revenue growth. And I just want to understand, in this lower-growth market, you're expecting pricing to scale up to 2.5% from 0 the last few years, your volume growth to accelerate. And I don't know -- it says 2015 to '20, so I don't know if you're counting '15 and '16 within that CAGR, which would be a pretty big upside for '17 through '20. But does that set up for trouble? I guess more importantly, how much of the 65% is built on revenue top line versus the costs that you've laid out?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the plan, revenue growth is an important driver of operating ratio improvement and bottom line improvement as well. And right now, it's a difficult environment in which to pitch growth. We understand that. That's why we're so focused on cost savings ri
componenttext: In the plan, revenue growth is an important driver of operating ratio improvement and bottom line improvement as well. And right now, it's a difficult environment in which to pitch growth. We understand that. That's why we're so focused on cost savings right now. Cost savings, keeping our service at the current level and running the safe railroad are our top priorities in 2016, and we will do what we need to do to achieve the results. That's the other thing to appreciate about the plan. It's a flexible plan, a dynamic plan. If we need to pivot to a different strategy, we certainly can and will.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then -- but is there a limit of how much in that 65% is tied to the top line versus your costs? I'm just trying to understand at least for the base case that you've said so as things change we can kind of understand what shifts need to be taken
componenttext: Okay. And then -- but is there a limit of how much in that 65% is tied to the top line versus your costs? I'm just trying to understand at least for the base case that you've said so as things change we can kind of understand what shifts need to be taken on maybe more aggressive cost cutting. Is the plan based half on top line, half on costs or -- as it is right now?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are elements of both in the plan. It's a balanced plan. We think it's the right plan for our markets, our customers and our franchise. It does assume some volume growth and pricing as well. Now Alan feels confident about the pricing potential here.
componenttext: There are elements of both in the plan. It's a balanced plan. We think it's the right plan for our markets, our customers and our franchise. It does assume some volume growth and pricing as well. Now Alan feels confident about the pricing potential here. The volume growth is obviously a bit more of a wildcard. We think we have the opportunity to grow volume over this 5-year period. Pricing, coupled with even modest growth, is an important driver of bottom line performance for us and everybody else in the industry. If we have to pivot to a different strategy and take the expenses down even more aggressively, we will.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could do my follow-up on Triple Crown, Alan. Maybe just a little bit on volumes. Why did the Triple Crown -- when you said that volume's not turning back to intermodal, did it lose to truck? Or are they still in transition? And then I guess, ulti
componenttext: And if I could do my follow-up on Triple Crown, Alan. Maybe just a little bit on volumes. Why did the Triple Crown -- when you said that volume's not turning back to intermodal, did it lose to truck? Or are they still in transition? And then I guess, ultimately, why was it eliminated? I presumed because it wasn't additive to margins, so I just want to understand that shift in the business, why you weren't able to recapture it in kind of different ways, whether it's through third party or what have you.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, that's a good question. We worked with our channel partners to get as much of it back as possible. But almost by definition, the Triple Crown franchise was set up not to compete with our conventional intermodal franchise, so there's not a lot of over
componenttext: Ken, that's a good question. We worked with our channel partners to get as much of it back as possible. But almost by definition, the Triple Crown franchise was set up not to compete with our conventional intermodal franchise, so there's not a lot of overlap. It's not yet fully defined how much will move back into our intermodal network. And frankly, Ken, we're seeing some move into our merchandise network, too, which, once again, underscores the benefit of our improved service product that our merchandise network can compete for Triple Crown business.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Remember...
componenttext: Remember...

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So still in transition is what you're saying? It's not -- because it seems like a lot of, obviously, that opportunity -- was it lost again to truck? Or is it still moving around?
componenttext: So still in transition is what you're saying? It's not -- because it seems like a lot of, obviously, that opportunity -- was it lost again to truck? Or is it still moving around?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, most of it will ultimately be lost to truck because our conventional network does not run in a lot of the lanes that Triple Crown ran in.
componenttext: Ken, most of it will ultimately be lost to truck because our conventional network does not run in a lot of the lanes that Triple Crown ran in.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The important takeaway here though is, as we have said, despite the volume decline, we expect the restructuring to be accretive to earnings modestly.
componenttext: The important takeaway here though is, as we have said, despite the volume decline, we expect the restructuring to be accretive to earnings modestly.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just follow up on the 2016 volume question to be clear on that front. Is your guidance for a sub-70 OR assuming that volumes are down this year? And if so, could you talk about the magnitude of the volume decline you're expecting?
componenttext: I wanted to just follow up on the 2016 volume question to be clear on that front. Is your guidance for a sub-70 OR assuming that volumes are down this year? And if so, could you talk about the magnitude of the volume decline you're expecting?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The volumes are currently in play right now, and it's a tough start to the year, no doubt about it. If we're heading into a recession, this is going to be a tough slug for everybody. We will pivot to additional cost-cutting if we have to. We -- the sub-70
componenttext: The volumes are currently in play right now, and it's a tough start to the year, no doubt about it. If we're heading into a recession, this is going to be a tough slug for everybody. We will pivot to additional cost-cutting if we have to. We -- the sub-70 operating ratio is our goal, and we're going to do whatever we possibly can, short of going into recession. That makes life difficult for all of us for sure. But sub 70 is our goal. We're working hard to achieve it through a combination of expense reductions and whatever volume and pricing increases we can manage.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And maybe to just follow up on the OR target for 2016. So you highlighted in 2015 the OR was 71.7% [ph] when you exclude the impact from Roanoke and Triple Crown. Is there any way to frame up how much of the improvement off of that base you
componenttext: Okay, got it. And maybe to just follow up on the OR target for 2016. So you highlighted in 2015 the OR was 71.7% [ph] when you exclude the impact from Roanoke and Triple Crown. Is there any way to frame up how much of the improvement off of that base you expect in 2016 just from the strategic changes you've made if you total up the impact from Roanoke, Triple Crown and some of the other changes in the coal network?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, remember we're comparing to GAAP results, including the restructuring charges in 2015. That gives you a head start on lower expenses right there in 2016, but that doesn't factor in the $130 million in productivity savings we're looking for.
componenttext: So again, remember we're comparing to GAAP results, including the restructuring charges in 2015. That gives you a head start on lower expenses right there in 2016, but that doesn't factor in the $130 million in productivity savings we're looking for.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one last quick one on that. Marta, sorry if I missed this. But D&A, obviously, has taken a step up. What's your expectation for D&A this year?
componenttext: Okay. And one last quick one on that. Marta, sorry if I missed this. But D&A, obviously, has taken a step up. What's your expectation for D&A this year?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pardon me, what did you say, depreciation?
componenttext: Pardon me, what did you say, depreciation?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Depreciation and the -- yes. That was up in part because of the Triple Crown restructuring.
componenttext: Depreciation and the -- yes. That was up in part because of the Triple Crown restructuring.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. So depreciation, when you exclude the restructuring charge, was up $10 million in the fourth quarter. And so we would expect a similar amount in each quarter -- to increase each quarter in 2016.
componenttext: Yes, yes. So depreciation, when you exclude the restructuring charge, was up $10 million in the fourth quarter. And so we would expect a similar amount in each quarter -- to increase each quarter in 2016.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Cherilyn Radbourne with TD Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Cherilyn Radbourne with TD Securities.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your service metrics improved quite significantly in Q4. But it looks like a lot of that was pretty back-end loaded. So from a cost perspective, even though your T&E overtime was down and your recrews were down, it would seem like you wouldn't have rea
componenttext: So your service metrics improved quite significantly in Q4. But it looks like a lot of that was pretty back-end loaded. So from a cost perspective, even though your T&E overtime was down and your recrews were down, it would seem like you wouldn't have realized that full benefit in Q4. I was just wondering if you could help us think about that particular issue.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's true, that's true. We did not see the full benefit of the service improvements in terms of expense reductions in Q4. Mike, talk a little bit about the trend and what we expect in the first quarter.
componenttext: That's true, that's true. We did not see the full benefit of the service improvements in terms of expense reductions in Q4. Mike, talk a little bit about the trend and what we expect in the first quarter.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look at the service metrics through the quarter, they did improve each month through the quarter, and it was near the end of the quarter that we got back to our historic highs, which is what we're currently operating at. And that's why we feel
componenttext: Yes. If you look at the service metrics through the quarter, they did improve each month through the quarter, and it was near the end of the quarter that we got back to our historic highs, which is what we're currently operating at. And that's why we feel like the productivity savings we've got going forward are going to be very achievable because we did get to that level now.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So do you happen to have what T&E over time and recrews would have looked like year-over-year in December as an example?
componenttext: So do you happen to have what T&E over time and recrews would have looked like year-over-year in December as an example?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hang on just a second. So what's the question?
componenttext: Hang on just a second. So what's the question?

componenttextpreview: What did it look like in December to give us a run rate for first quarter?
componenttext: What did it look like in December to give us a run rate for first quarter?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just for T&E? Well, I gave the whole $13 million for the entire quarter, Mike, with the reduction in overtime. And so what we're saying is that occurred disproportionately in December. So...
componenttext: Just for T&E? Well, I gave the whole $13 million for the entire quarter, Mike, with the reduction in overtime. And so what we're saying is that occurred disproportionately in December. So...

componenttext: Right, correct. We don't have that broken out just by December.
