headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alan, you mentioned a lot of core pricing going up or even flat in some categories. Can you give us -- it sounds like there are some competition pressuring some of the volumes in different instances. Can you talk about, overall, your thoughts on pricing g
componenttext: Alan, you mentioned a lot of core pricing going up or even flat in some categories. Can you give us -- it sounds like there are some competition pressuring some of the volumes in different instances. Can you talk about, overall, your thoughts on pricing given what's going on in the truck market going -- what's given on the different commodities on an aggregate basis?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ken, pricing is still moving up for us. We accelerated pricing year-over-year. We are facing some competition with respect to truck. It doesn't mean we're taking lower prices. It more, Ken, limits our upside potential in certain truck-competitive mar
componenttext: Yes. Ken, pricing is still moving up for us. We accelerated pricing year-over-year. We are facing some competition with respect to truck. It doesn't mean we're taking lower prices. It more, Ken, limits our upside potential in certain truck-competitive markets.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm sorry, just so in aggregate, still kind of above inflation. I mean, can you give a parameter of how, in aggregate, you're thinking about pricing overall?
componenttext: So I'm sorry, just so in aggregate, still kind of above inflation. I mean, can you give a parameter of how, in aggregate, you're thinking about pricing overall?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We are taking a measured and disciplined approach to pricing. We are focused on competitive pricing above rail inflation. We continue to exceed that, and we are exceeding the pricing levels that we achieved last year.
componenttext: Yes. We are taking a measured and disciplined approach to pricing. We are focused on competitive pricing above rail inflation. We continue to exceed that, and we are exceeding the pricing levels that we achieved last year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Wonderful. And then a follow-up on a different subject. But just looking -- Jim, talking about your long-term double-digit growth and sub-65 target, great to see the progress with the $200 million. When you think about that $650 million to get to th
componenttext: Okay. Wonderful. And then a follow-up on a different subject. But just looking -- Jim, talking about your long-term double-digit growth and sub-65 target, great to see the progress with the $200 million. When you think about that $650 million to get to that scale, is that new programs? Is that shutting additional yards? You mentioned one of the hump yards you shut down. Can you kind of give maybe some parameters on other -- as you've moved along in this development, your thoughts on how you're going to get there?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, we've previously outlined a goal of $650 million in annual productivity savings by 2020, and we are making good progress on that thus far. We're only 6 months into a 5-year plan, so we still have a lot of ground to cover. But the big buckets o
componenttext: Sure. Well, we've previously outlined a goal of $650 million in annual productivity savings by 2020, and we are making good progress on that thus far. We're only 6 months into a 5-year plan, so we still have a lot of ground to cover. But the big buckets of that $650 million, as you know, are in comp and benefits, fuel consumption, locomotive maintenance and reduced equipment costs and fees. And we're making progress in all of those areas. We have plans in place to continue pushing productivity gains for the remainder of this year and the 5-year plan period.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you a little bit about how we might think about operating ratio in the second half. It sounds like you're having a little more constructive outlook for volumes if there could be some improvements. I know you've got good operating leverage
componenttext: I wanted to ask you a little bit about how we might think about operating ratio in the second half. It sounds like you're having a little more constructive outlook for volumes if there could be some improvements. I know you've got good operating leverage in your scheduled carload network; presumably, intermodal as well. So I'm just wondering -- I think you talked about some cost pressures from incentive comp and so forth. How would you think about operating ratio in the second half and maybe the impact of operating leverage if volume improves relative to what might be happening on the cost side?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tom. Thank you. We still are guiding towards the below 70 operating ratio for the full year. You are correct that we had good movement on that in the second quarter. For the remainder of the year, the 2 items that I will point out, you mentioned one
componenttext: Yes, Tom. Thank you. We still are guiding towards the below 70 operating ratio for the full year. You are correct that we had good movement on that in the second quarter. For the remainder of the year, the 2 items that I will point out, you mentioned one of them, that will cause the 68.4 to maybe go up a little bit but still stay below 70 is the incentive comp and then also the rate of decline in the materials expenses. But we're comfortable with our -- continuing our guidance of below 70 for the full year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how do you think about volumes like -- I mean, I guess, if we see volumes develop a little bit better and you do see kind of less versus third quarter and then improvement year-over-year in fourth quarter, is it fair to think that there'll be nice imp
componenttext: And how do you think about volumes like -- I mean, I guess, if we see volumes develop a little bit better and you do see kind of less versus third quarter and then improvement year-over-year in fourth quarter, is it fair to think that there'll be nice impacts in terms of operating leverage and nice impacts to the OR? Or should we be kind of cautious on how we anticipate that coming through?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- certainly, volume growth represents upside. Volume growth beyond our expectations would represent upside, particularly if it occurs in lines of business with high operating leverage. So yes, that's certainly a possibility. We believe we have the ca
componenttext: The -- certainly, volume growth represents upside. Volume growth beyond our expectations would represent upside, particularly if it occurs in lines of business with high operating leverage. So yes, that's certainly a possibility. We believe we have the capacity to take advantage of natural operating leverage in those businesses. Now I'll turn it over to Alan to talk a little bit more about the volume outlook, generally, in the second half.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I spoke a little bit about it in the remarks as I walked through our different commodities. For us, it's going to be a coal and intermodal outlook, and merchandise ups and downs are going to be dependent upon energy prices. If you take a look at the
componenttext: Tom, I spoke a little bit about it in the remarks as I walked through our different commodities. For us, it's going to be a coal and intermodal outlook, and merchandise ups and downs are going to be dependent upon energy prices. If you take a look at the forward curve for commodities and energy prices, the fourth quarter is higher than it stands today, although I'll note that just this month, WTI has pulled back 12%. So that creates some caution to our outlook. But generally, we see that sequential growth in the third quarter, fourth quarter comps should be much easier for us because fourth quarter last year is when we saw the commodities downdraft, and then we saw the Triple Crown restructuring towards the middle of the quarter.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ravi Shanker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ravi Shanker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to clarify a response to a previous question on pricing. Did you say that year-on-year pricing is actually above where it was last year? Or is just that you're getting higher price versus last year?
componenttext: I just want to clarify a response to a previous question on pricing. Did you say that year-on-year pricing is actually above where it was last year? Or is just that you're getting higher price versus last year?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ravi, I did say that our year-on-year pricing is higher than it was -- stood at this point last year. We're taking a long-term approach as our customers. There is an expectation that the trucking market is going to tighten at some point next year, and we
componenttext: Ravi, I did say that our year-on-year pricing is higher than it was -- stood at this point last year. We're taking a long-term approach as our customers. There is an expectation that the trucking market is going to tighten at some point next year, and we started to see some sequential improvement in demand in the truck market just this month. And we're leveraging the benefit of our improved service product.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And not that anyone knows what the weather would do, but does your 4Q volume growth forecast assume a normal winter or a warm winter, just given that we're having record heat this year?
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And not that anyone knows what the weather would do, but does your 4Q volume growth forecast assume a normal winter or a warm winter, just given that we're having record heat this year?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are assuming normal weather patterns. And certainly, weather and natural gas prices will determine how quickly stockpiles return to normal within the coal network. In any case, we don't believe that, that will occur until sometime next year.
componenttext: We are assuming normal weather patterns. And certainly, weather and natural gas prices will determine how quickly stockpiles return to normal within the coal network. In any case, we don't believe that, that will occur until sometime next year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Allison Landry with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Allison Landry with Credit Suisse.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on the OR commentary for the back half. I just want to make sure I understand it correctly. So potentially, a little bit worse sequentially in Q3, but then maybe with volume growth in Q4, the normal sequential deterioration that
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the OR commentary for the back half. I just want to make sure I understand it correctly. So potentially, a little bit worse sequentially in Q3, but then maybe with volume growth in Q4, the normal sequential deterioration that you'd see it in the OR, then maybe the sort of cadence is up. Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the right -- directionally, I think you're right, Allison. I think the right way to think about it is it's very dependent on the volumes to come. So you all are familiar with our incremental margin hierarchy, which is the -- when the volumes come
componenttext: I think the right -- directionally, I think you're right, Allison. I think the right way to think about it is it's very dependent on the volumes to come. So you all are familiar with our incremental margin hierarchy, which is the -- when the volumes come back in merchandise, that is the most positive incrementally and then coal and then intermodal because of the specific costs that it has. So it's very dependent on the volume. You're not going to see a very -- you're not going to see a huge change in any of these items. I guided to the 2 specific items in expense going forward that will be slightly different in the third and fourth quarters. But as Mike and the operating team continue to run the railroads very, very efficiently, you're operating expense-wise of what you saw in the second quarter.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then thinking about CapEx and maybe if you could provide any initial thoughts on spending for 2017 considering what will likely be 2 consecutive down years for GTMs and then the percentage of the locomotive fleet that's in storag
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then thinking about CapEx and maybe if you could provide any initial thoughts on spending for 2017 considering what will likely be 2 consecutive down years for GTMs and then the percentage of the locomotive fleet that's in storage?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take that one, Allison. So we have previously guided to CapEx at 19% of revenue through the completion of PTC. Thereafter, we expect to be able to reduce CapEx by several percentage points relative to sales. And we've been aggressive this year
componenttext: Sure. I'll take that one, Allison. So we have previously guided to CapEx at 19% of revenue through the completion of PTC. Thereafter, we expect to be able to reduce CapEx by several percentage points relative to sales. And we've been aggressive this year on CapEx in light of volumes, revenue and cash flow that have not met initial expectations. We have reduced CapEx, as Marta mentioned, fully $200 million relative to our original plan. And that's important because we're focused on making the investments we need to make. We will invest as required to operate safely, efficiently and require -- and provide a high-level service product. Beyond that, it's all about the returns. If they're there, we'll invest more. If they're not, we won't. We recognize the need to generate ample free cash flow for shareholders. And that's all part of our strategy.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just a follow-up on that. So Marta, I think you had mentioned at some of the conferences in the last few months that you guys are still expecting to acquire, I think, another 50 new locomotive units next year. Is that still the way th
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just a follow-up on that. So Marta, I think you had mentioned at some of the conferences in the last few months that you guys are still expecting to acquire, I think, another 50 new locomotive units next year. Is that still the way that you guys are thinking about it?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct. We have 50 new locomotives coming in next year.
componenttext: That's correct. We have 50 new locomotives coming in next year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citi.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on that CapEx question and just sort of -- just conceptually, thinking about maybe the cadence of volume growth as you look out over the course of the next year or so and sort of the progress of locomotives that you need to take o
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on that CapEx question and just sort of -- just conceptually, thinking about maybe the cadence of volume growth as you look out over the course of the next year or so and sort of the progress of locomotives that you need to take on. I guess, maybe the question comes up of why wouldn't we maybe see CapEx kind of fall a little bit before PTC spending goes down? You do have sort of lower incremental spending on equipment coming. I just want to make sure I kind of get all of the moving parts when you think about that maybe for 2017, 2018.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like turn it over to Mike to talk about our locomotive strategy in particular. So that's obviously a significant capital budget item. To reiterate what I said a minute ago, we will invest as necessary to provide a safe, efficient, high-service product
componenttext: I'd like turn it over to Mike to talk about our locomotive strategy in particular. So that's obviously a significant capital budget item. To reiterate what I said a minute ago, we will invest as necessary to provide a safe, efficient, high-service product. After that, we'll see. It just depends on the returns on the incremental dollar of investment. What I would love for investors to take away from this call is our commitment to disciplined capital spending in the here and now. And as noted, we've tightened the reins on capital spending this year, just as we have on expense, to reflect lower-than-expected revenue and cash flow. And that's really important in our business. It's an asset-intensive business. We've got to stay disciplined on CapEx as with expenses. And that's part of our plan to drive free cash flow. Mike, why don't you to talk a little bit about the locomotive strategy specifically?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. While we still do have the 50 locomotives new next year, we continue to progress down the really innovative DC-to-AC rebuild strategy that we have in place, which, over the next several years, will allow us to bring the age of our fleet down and get
componenttext: Yes. While we still do have the 50 locomotives new next year, we continue to progress down the really innovative DC-to-AC rebuild strategy that we have in place, which, over the next several years, will allow us to bring the age of our fleet down and get good locomotives at a much lower capital cost than new.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. So it's productivity as well. That makes sense. Can I ask a question, just a follow-up on productivity, the $200 million or better, I think, for this year? Can you give us a sense of maybe sort of how that might be portioned out into
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. So it's productivity as well. That makes sense. Can I ask a question, just a follow-up on productivity, the $200 million or better, I think, for this year? Can you give us a sense of maybe sort of how that might be portioned out into the back half of the year, maybe where you are and kind of how we should be thinking about it for 3Q and 4Q?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've outlined an annual productivity objective, and that's where we're going to stay in terms of our productivity goals. We have seen significant progress in productivity in the first half. Obviously, you see that in the numbers. We said that we conti
componenttext: So we've outlined an annual productivity objective, and that's where we're going to stay in terms of our productivity goals. We have seen significant progress in productivity in the first half. Obviously, you see that in the numbers. We said that we continue to believe we can do $200 million or better for the full year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So thinking about roughly equal or any sense of what the progress has been towards that goal this year?
componenttext: Okay. So thinking about roughly equal or any sense of what the progress has been towards that goal this year?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did say in the first quarter that we front-loaded some of the productivity. You saw that in the first quarter, and we continued on track during the second quarter. For the full year, we're still thinking we can do at least $200 million.
componenttext: We did say in the first quarter that we front-loaded some of the productivity. You saw that in the first quarter, and we continued on track during the second quarter. For the full year, we're still thinking we can do at least $200 million.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And generally speaking, the front-end loading that Jim described is in the materials area. And so the detail that we gave with regard to the $42 million materials reduction in the first quarter and then $26 million this quarter, you can see that fr
componenttext: Right. And generally speaking, the front-end loading that Jim described is in the materials area. And so the detail that we gave with regard to the $42 million materials reduction in the first quarter and then $26 million this quarter, you can see that front-end loading there because we expect $15 million going forward. So if you kind of look at that difference, that's the area where we had the front-end loading.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bascome Majors with Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bascome Majors with Susquehanna.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The STB has promised a decision on the NITL's competitive switching proposal by the end of this month, which is just a few days away. I was hoping you could shed some light on what your expectations are to both the timing and the content of that when we r
componenttext: The STB has promised a decision on the NITL's competitive switching proposal by the end of this month, which is just a few days away. I was hoping you could shed some light on what your expectations are to both the timing and the content of that when we receive it based on your engagement with agency.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The STB had publicized a schedule for issuing rulings in that case and several others earlier this year. My understanding is that's not a deadline. It's not binding on the STB. It's their current expectation as to when they'll issue rulings. So I don't ha
componenttext: The STB had publicized a schedule for issuing rulings in that case and several others earlier this year. My understanding is that's not a deadline. It's not binding on the STB. It's their current expectation as to when they'll issue rulings. So I don't have any further insight to shed on the time line or what may come from the STB. We have certainly made our case for the status quo when it comes to the competition in the industry. And we'll just have to wait and see how the STB rules there and then the other matters that are pending.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Maybe one more, the truck competition in your carload merchandise business. Can you shed a little light on where you might be bleeding share to truck or either seeing a bit more acute pressure on price in some of these carload business as you
componenttext: Understood. Maybe one more, the truck competition in your carload merchandise business. Can you shed a little light on where you might be bleeding share to truck or either seeing a bit more acute pressure on price in some of these carload business as you kind of alluded to earlier? And from a high level, do you have a sense of how much this has been a drag on your overall volumes?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bascome, if we talk about intermodal, your question is specific to merchandise and carload, correct? So I'll address that. I mentioned the fact that we're seeing additional competition within our ag markets. That also has to do with the strength of the cr
componenttext: Bascome, if we talk about intermodal, your question is specific to merchandise and carload, correct? So I'll address that. I mentioned the fact that we're seeing additional competition within our ag markets. That also has to do with the strength of the crop in the Southeast. It opens up local corn into our network, which can move via truck. We're seeing some truck competition in the paper market into the Southeast. So it certainly has had an impact, as we know, on our domestic intermodal volumes and also on our carload business. Going forward, it's -- we're going to be looking closely at energy prices, the impact they have on truck, on truck availability and on commodity prices and retail inventories.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Salmon with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Salmon with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to kind of circle back to Chris's question of running productivity. You guys had done a good job extending train lengths. They were up a little bit in the quarter. However, if I'm looking at headcount per carload, that was essentially flat. Can
componenttext: I'm going to kind of circle back to Chris's question of running productivity. You guys had done a good job extending train lengths. They were up a little bit in the quarter. However, if I'm looking at headcount per carload, that was essentially flat. Can you walk me through some of the puts and takes and what it would take to kind of get back to a little under 70 where you peaked out a couple of years ago with regard to headcount per carload? Is this a mix issue? Or should we be thinking about a lot of operating leverage as volumes build particularly in the merchandise and intermodal?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There is a mix issue there. And as volumes are softening, we take train starts out of the network to build up other trains. And that's the balancing act. You don't want to do that real quickly because you don't want to hurt the service on the network
componenttext: Yes. There is a mix issue there. And as volumes are softening, we take train starts out of the network to build up other trains. And that's the balancing act. You don't want to do that real quickly because you don't want to hurt the service on the network. So that's the challenge there, but the good news is, going forward, that gives you a great operating leverage. And for us, we've got capacity on the trains in all commodity groups really. We've got capacity on the network, and we've got capacity in our resources of locomotives and crews. So we've got a lot of leverage to the upside. But if volumes remain soft, we'll continue to whittle it with the resources to make sure that all the productivity and efficiency is there.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you give us a sense of the -- how much below you are the optimal train size opportunity in kind of your merchandise and intermodal networks as I think about kind of what that leverage could be?
componenttext: And can you give us a sense of the -- how much below you are the optimal train size opportunity in kind of your merchandise and intermodal networks as I think about kind of what that leverage could be?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got a good ways to go both on the merchandise side and the intermodal side. We're very comfortable where that's at, being able to add more units to both of those trains before we start train starts. And then if we need to do train starts, we'll add
componenttext: We've got a good ways to go both on the merchandise side and the intermodal side. We're very comfortable where that's at, being able to add more units to both of those trains before we start train starts. And then if we need to do train starts, we'll add that on. That will be a good news story. But we feel very good about capacity on both of those. Particularly the intermodal, we have such a great double stack network that gives us a lot of efficiency.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any sense in terms of just the magnitude of delta versus kind of optimal?
componenttext: And any sense in terms of just the magnitude of delta versus kind of optimal?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, because I think you get down into the lane level and the terminal level. A lot of details there, but we take every opportunity we can.
componenttext: No, because I think you get down into the lane level and the terminal level. A lot of details there, but we take every opportunity we can.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Seidl with Cowen.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Seidl with Cowen.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick things for me. One, following up on your commentary in the intermodal versus truck marketplace, I think you guys said that there had been some sequential improvement, especially over the last month. I was wondering if you could elaborate on that
componenttext: Two quick things for me. One, following up on your commentary in the intermodal versus truck marketplace, I think you guys said that there had been some sequential improvement, especially over the last month. I was wondering if you could elaborate on that. And let us know, has there been an increase in sort of truck spot pricing? Has there been a decrease in available trucks? Any color would be appreciated on that comment.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, we have seen an increase in truck spot pricing. It's increasing sequentially. It's not increasing year-over-year.
componenttext: Jason, we have seen an increase in truck spot pricing. It's increasing sequentially. It's not increasing year-over-year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's a good update. Also, maybe this one might be for Jim. Jim, I think when we came into this year in terms of the sort of total restructuring plan at Norfolk, you talked about 1,600 miles of track divestitures and that you would do 1,000 -- or a
componenttext: Okay. That's a good update. Also, maybe this one might be for Jim. Jim, I think when we came into this year in terms of the sort of total restructuring plan at Norfolk, you talked about 1,600 miles of track divestitures and that you would do 1,000 -- or at least, let us know where the 1,000 was going by the end of this year. I think you've done just over 300 miles so far this year. Wondering if you can give us an update.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, we're making good progress there as in other areas of productivity and restructuring, and we're on track to hit or exceed that mileage goal for the full year. Mike, why don't you talk a little bit more specifically about some of the areas wher
componenttext: Sure. Well, we're making good progress there as in other areas of productivity and restructuring, and we're on track to hit or exceed that mileage goal for the full year. Mike, why don't you talk a little bit more specifically about some of the areas where we're working on that?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we've got a lot going on there. We've got 2 pieces to this. This is the -- where we're doing some short lining, and we've got a short line of the West Virginia Secondary that will happen here, actually, next week. So that's a piece of it. We're lo
componenttext: Yes. So we've got a lot going on there. We've got 2 pieces to this. This is the -- where we're doing some short lining, and we've got a short line of the West Virginia Secondary that will happen here, actually, next week. So that's a piece of it. We're looking at other parts of the railroad as well. But the other piece to it on the network rationalization is where we've spent a lot of time looking at where we can take resources out of the track structure without hurting service or safety. And that's been a good news story. We've got over 1,000 miles of that that's already happened on the railroad and some of the benefits that we've seen in our cost reduction as related to that. More to come as we go forward, so we feel very comfortable about meeting or exceeding that. And I think we're thinking about giving an update on the third quarter on the details of actually where these are at. But anyway, kind of a wrap-up is we're ahead of schedule on it and we're seeing good costs come out of the network. But more importantly, the safety and service has remained high in those areas.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Group with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Group with Wolfe Research.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marta, can you help clarify one thing? So I get the incentive comp is a year-over-year headwind in the third quarter. Is it a sequential headwind from 2Q to 3Q?
componenttext: Marta, can you help clarify one thing? So I get the incentive comp is a year-over-year headwind in the third quarter. Is it a sequential headwind from 2Q to 3Q?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a very small sequential headwind going forward, as you saw it wasn't one of the year-over-year items that I needed to highlight. So that gives you an indication of the smaller size.
componenttext: It's a very small sequential headwind going forward, as you saw it wasn't one of the year-over-year items that I needed to highlight. So that gives you an indication of the smaller size.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if it's a small sequential headwind and you're expecting some volume improvement, I guess, I'm a little confused why you're not -- why you think the operating ratio gets worse in the third quarter than the second quarter.
componenttext: So if it's a small sequential headwind and you're expecting some volume improvement, I guess, I'm a little confused why you're not -- why you think the operating ratio gets worse in the third quarter than the second quarter.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we're really just talking very -- we're talking very tiny basis points. I think in response to Allison's question, I think the best thing when you're looking at the expense projection sequentially going forward other than the 2 items that I mentio
componenttext: I mean, we're really just talking very -- we're talking very tiny basis points. I think in response to Allison's question, I think the best thing when you're looking at the expense projection sequentially going forward other than the 2 items that I mentioned, the incentive comp and the materials, you -- we think you will see us at about the run rate that we had in the second quarter. So we're really talking degrees -- very small degrees. And again, I will emphasize that it depends on the volume growth and the commodities that it comes in.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes sense. Can you give an update just on the fuel surcharge side and how much of the business you've transitioned over?
componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. Can you give an update just on the fuel surcharge side and how much of the business you've transitioned over?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. First and foremost, we are focused on price. And so as we enter into any negotiation, that's our target initially. We have been successful and made some progress. And right now, about 40% of our revenue is tied to WTI.
componenttext: Yes, Scott. First and foremost, we are focused on price. And so as we enter into any negotiation, that's our target initially. We have been successful and made some progress. And right now, about 40% of our revenue is tied to WTI.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, Alan, can you just give us an update? What's the mix of your coal business in terms of how much is App versus Illinois Basin and PRB today?
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, Alan, can you just give us an update? What's the mix of your coal business in terms of how much is App versus Illinois Basin and PRB today?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the second quarter, we saw a mix increase of Central App. So we had about 34% of our volume was Central App; about 30% was Northern App; Illinois Basin was about 21%; and then PRB, Scott, filled in the rest.
componenttext: So in the second quarter, we saw a mix increase of Central App. So we had about 34% of our volume was Central App; about 30% was Northern App; Illinois Basin was about 21%; and then PRB, Scott, filled in the rest.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first, I was wondering if you could just comment on how you're thinking about the progression of your intermodal volumes in the back half of the year. And bigger picture, do you think this recent weakness in intermodal volumes that we have seen for the
componenttext: So first, I was wondering if you could just comment on how you're thinking about the progression of your intermodal volumes in the back half of the year. And bigger picture, do you think this recent weakness in intermodal volumes that we have seen for the industry as a whole is a temporary headwind? Or do you have concern the consumer could be rolling over?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Justin, we think we're going to have continued improvement in our intermodal volumes. June was a good month for us. We see continued growth as we and our customers see the benefit of our improved service product. Secondly, our customers are preparing for
componenttext: Justin, we think we're going to have continued improvement in our intermodal volumes. June was a good month for us. We see continued growth as we and our customers see the benefit of our improved service product. Secondly, our customers are preparing for a tightness in truck capacity. And what you're seeing there is more growth with asset-based carriers. So we do think it's a temporary headwind. As fuel prices go up, that will also benefit us. But certainly, we're paying close attention to retail inventory levels.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But just to be clear, you think your intermodal volumes will be up in the back half. Is that what you said?
componenttext: Okay. But just to be clear, you think your intermodal volumes will be up in the back half. Is that what you said?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ex Triple Crown.
componenttext: Yes. Ex Triple Crown.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ex Triple Crown. Okay. Got you. Secondly, we've always heard about coal being the highest-margin business for the rails. But with your coal volumes down over 20% year-to-date and the pressure we have seen over the last couple of years, has this changed? H
componenttext: Ex Triple Crown. Okay. Got you. Secondly, we've always heard about coal being the highest-margin business for the rails. But with your coal volumes down over 20% year-to-date and the pressure we have seen over the last couple of years, has this changed? Has the gap between coal margins and your consolidated margins closed?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: There continues to be pressure on our coal franchise. That market is dynamic and so are we. And so we're focused on improving the profitability and the returns on all of our lines of business.
componenttext: There continues to be pressure on our coal franchise. That market is dynamic and so are we. And so we're focused on improving the profitability and the returns on all of our lines of business.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But that gap between coal and everything else really hasn't changed?
componenttext: Okay. But that gap between coal and everything else really hasn't changed?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I suggested, we're focused on improving the profitability on all lines of our business.
componenttext: As I suggested, we're focused on improving the profitability on all lines of our business.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jim, appreciate that you guys managed through a pretty difficult second quarter with a sub-70 OR. But we do have a lot of the industry that's running even sub-65 OR, if not even well below that in the current volume environment. So -- and as we've talk
componenttext: So Jim, appreciate that you guys managed through a pretty difficult second quarter with a sub-70 OR. But we do have a lot of the industry that's running even sub-65 OR, if not even well below that in the current volume environment. So -- and as we've talked a lot about the OR progression kind of sequentially flattish, if not even up a little bit, into the back half of the year, how much of your productivity savings are really just hoping for volume growth versus -- what more can you do structurally? I mean, we've seen Triple Crown; we've seen the hump yard closures; we've seen you go from 2 to 3 operating regions -- or 3 to 2. So what structurally is left in the network that you can identify from a cost standpoint?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the key to delivering on a plan is flexibility, and that's what we've demonstrated in the second quarter. The plan is dynamic. It is flexible and able to address changing market conditions, as we've outlined. We will continue to evaluate efficiencie
componenttext: Well, the key to delivering on a plan is flexibility, and that's what we've demonstrated in the second quarter. The plan is dynamic. It is flexible and able to address changing market conditions, as we've outlined. We will continue to evaluate efficiencies in all areas and ensure that we have the opportunity to adjust things going forward as necessary. Certainly, there is a component of growth assumed in our longer-range plan, and we believe we'll see that. If we don't, we will make adjustments as necessary to achieve our goals.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But as of now, I mean, there's nothing really structurally on the plate that you're looking at changing operationally for the company?
componenttext: Okay. But as of now, I mean, there's nothing really structurally on the plate that you're looking at changing operationally for the company?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've made a number of changes that I would characterize as structural already, and we'll be on the lookout for further opportunities there. Cost cutting is always a combination of short-term cost reductions in response to immediate business conditions an
componenttext: We've made a number of changes that I would characterize as structural already, and we'll be on the lookout for further opportunities there. Cost cutting is always a combination of short-term cost reductions in response to immediate business conditions and then the long-term outlook on structure. And we have initiatives in place in both areas, both short-term reductions as necessary and longer-term structural activities that will help to shape the cost structure of the company in the future.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a real quick clarification on CapEx. I know we talked a little bit about the outlook heading into next year and years beyond. But should we be thinking CapEx actually can come down?
componenttext: Okay. And just a real quick clarification on CapEx. I know we talked a little bit about the outlook heading into next year and years beyond. But should we be thinking CapEx actually can come down?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Post PTC, we have guided to CapEx below current levels relative to sales. So yes, when we get to that point. As I've said, the keys are safety, efficiency and customer service. That forms your baseline for capital spending. Beyond that baseline, it's all
componenttext: Post PTC, we have guided to CapEx below current levels relative to sales. So yes, when we get to that point. As I've said, the keys are safety, efficiency and customer service. That forms your baseline for capital spending. Beyond that baseline, it's all about the returns on the incremental investment. And we will look carefully at every additional dollar we spend. As I mentioned, what we would love investors to focus on out of this call is the way we have managed CapEx this year in response to business conditions. We have been every bit as determined to modulate CapEx as we have expenses. And that's our commitment going forward as well.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Ossenbeck with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Ossenbeck with JPMorgan.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alan, I just want to get your view on export coal trends going volatile, but you did a little bit better than the 3 million per quarter in 2Q. So if you have coking coal benchmark near 100 and your API 2 is close to 60, do you think you can perhaps run cl
componenttext: Alan, I just want to get your view on export coal trends going volatile, but you did a little bit better than the 3 million per quarter in 2Q. So if you have coking coal benchmark near 100 and your API 2 is close to 60, do you think you can perhaps run closer to 3.6 throughout the rest of the year if the pricing holds? Or was there something kind of one-off that helped reduce volumes this quarter?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, it is an extremely volatile market. We're impacted by the health of the producers and bankruptcies. They're doing everything they can to produce coal and sell it overseas, but it's highly dependent upon global demand and seaborne trade. And right n
componenttext: Brian, it is an extremely volatile market. We're impacted by the health of the producers and bankruptcies. They're doing everything they can to produce coal and sell it overseas, but it's highly dependent upon global demand and seaborne trade. And right now, those are fairly weak. So our guidance has typically been 2.5 to 3 million tons a quarter. We exceeded that, as you noted, last quarter. We're going to continue with that guidance for this quarter, but there's -- it's so volatile, and there's a lot of pressures there that it would be difficult to call an upside or downside to that.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And then I don't know if you have a comment on specifically. But if you could, in the context of the long-term strategic plan, what type of options do you think there are for Lamberts Point, considering the way that the markets are now,
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And then I don't know if you have a comment on specifically. But if you could, in the context of the long-term strategic plan, what type of options do you think there are for Lamberts Point, considering the way that the markets are now, China demands down, and clearly, the volatility remains? As you've thought through, is that built into the strategic plan at all?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: What is built into the strategic plan is our continuing focus on monitoring our markets and adjusting our resources accordingly. And you saw that as we've idled Ashtabula and we've idled Knoxville yard and we combined the Pocahontas division with the Virg
componenttext: What is built into the strategic plan is our continuing focus on monitoring our markets and adjusting our resources accordingly. And you saw that as we've idled Ashtabula and we've idled Knoxville yard and we combined the Pocahontas division with the Virginia division, which was effectively a coal play.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And just a one quick follow-up for Marta. In the past, you've given out the net fuel impact, which is obviously quite significant in 2015. I think it was about $20 million unfavorable in the first quarter. Do you have the impact on where it was in
componenttext: Right. And just a one quick follow-up for Marta. In the past, you've given out the net fuel impact, which is obviously quite significant in 2015. I think it was about $20 million unfavorable in the first quarter. Do you have the impact on where it was in the second quarter?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at our fuel surcharge revenue, it was $50 million in the quarter, which was $69 million reduction. So comparing that to the drop in fuel expense of $81 million, there was a little bit of a net, a small tailwind, in the quarter.
componenttext: Well, if you look at our fuel surcharge revenue, it was $50 million in the quarter, which was $69 million reduction. So comparing that to the drop in fuel expense of $81 million, there was a little bit of a net, a small tailwind, in the quarter.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned in the prepared remarks in the automotive sector some competitive losses and lesser demand impacting the back half. Could you just elaborate a little bit on what you're seeing and perhaps the -- some feel for the magnitude what that might be
componenttext: You mentioned in the prepared remarks in the automotive sector some competitive losses and lesser demand impacting the back half. Could you just elaborate a little bit on what you're seeing and perhaps the -- some feel for the magnitude what that might be?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, we said that there are some specific models typically in passenger cars in which the plants are undergoing retooling, which are going to impact our volumes in the second half of the year. We also, as you'll recall, on our first quarter call pointed
componenttext: Scott, we said that there are some specific models typically in passenger cars in which the plants are undergoing retooling, which are going to impact our volumes in the second half of the year. We also, as you'll recall, on our first quarter call pointed towards the fact that comps would get a lot more difficult towards the latter end of the year because in the second half of 2015, service started to improve and we started to work through the backlog of shipments in the automotive network. That, in and of itself, will put pressure on year-over-year comps. We still feel consistent with what we said on the first quarter call that our overall volumes for the year in automotive are going to approximate the North American vehicle growth, which Wards right now puts at 1.1%.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I don't know if I -- you might have mentioned, I don't know if I caught it, the $100 million reduction in the CapEx this year. Could you elaborate on maybe what the top 2 or 3 categories are that you're able to trim in the here and now?
componenttext: Great. And then I don't know if I -- you might have mentioned, I don't know if I caught it, the $100 million reduction in the CapEx this year. Could you elaborate on maybe what the top 2 or 3 categories are that you're able to trim in the here and now?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Yes, Scott. Well, we've actually so for this year had $200 million in capital reductions. On the first quarter call, we lowered our CapEx forecast for the full year from $2.1 billion to $2 billion. Today, we've indicated, as Jim has mentioned a
componenttext: All right. Yes, Scott. Well, we've actually so for this year had $200 million in capital reductions. On the first quarter call, we lowered our CapEx forecast for the full year from $2.1 billion to $2 billion. Today, we've indicated, as Jim has mentioned a couple times, that we are modulating our capital. We're being proactive as we see the volume softening and lowered another $100 million. So we're currently at $1.9 billion. And the reductions have come in 3 general areas: The first area is in the unit costs. And that's a very good news story because what Mike and the operating team has been able to do is in our maintenance of way area, they are reducing because we have more track time and other efficiencies that they have come up with. The self-constructed assets that we do on our right of way, they've got less labor costs per unit. They have also got slightly lower pricing on some of the materials, so the reductions there are in the unit costs. So they're putting in the same number of units that we have planned, but it costs less. The next biggest grouping is in the locomotive area. Mike mentioned that we do a lot of our locomotive work in house. We have rebuilds that we had in the capital plan. As the year went on and the volumes didn't come, we pulled out some of those rebuilds. So we have the flexibility to defer those and do them at a later year when we need the locomotives. And the third area is spread around all the various parts of the capital budget. And that is where we've either been able to trim the costs, in some cases, in the materials cost, or we've been able to defer it because of the volumes have not come. An example of that would be parking at an intermodal terminal. So we might say where we're going to expand parking, but we'll do it next year.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Larkin with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Larkin with Stifel.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to focus in on intermodal a little bit if that's okay. In your case, international freight was a little better than domestic. That's kind of backwards relative to what we're seeing across the broader industry. Is there any particular reason wh
componenttext: Just wanted to focus in on intermodal a little bit if that's okay. In your case, international freight was a little better than domestic. That's kind of backwards relative to what we're seeing across the broader industry. Is there any particular reason why your intermodal is up? You've apparently grabbed some market share there. Is that a service issue? Is that pricing, cost differential, just geographic franchise advantage? What's really driving that? And then what's holding back the growth of domestic? Was it the service quality issues, which perhaps caused a bit of a market share loss? Are you gaining any of that market share loss back on the domestic side?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, the international is a story of our network reach, and it's a story of a shift, although moderate but continual, from West Coast ports towards the East Coast ports. And certainly, our port partners on the East Coast feel that the widening of the Pan
componenttext: John, the international is a story of our network reach, and it's a story of a shift, although moderate but continual, from West Coast ports towards the East Coast ports. And certainly, our port partners on the East Coast feel that the widening of the Panama Canal will continue that progression. With respect to our domestic intermodal franchise, that has clearly been limited by surplus dry van capacity in the truck market and then high retail inventory levels. As both of those moderate, we'll continue to see -- we'll start to see growth in that network. And our continued improvements in our service product are helping us convert from highway to rail.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on the labor side, are there any major labor contract negotiations forthcoming here? And what would you expect labor costs fully loaded with fringes to inflate at here over the next couple of years?
componenttext: Got it. And then on the labor side, are there any major labor contract negotiations forthcoming here? And what would you expect labor costs fully loaded with fringes to inflate at here over the next couple of years?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll turn it over to Marta to comment on projected labor inflation. The entire industry, as you know, is engaged in collective bargaining over the terms of industry-wide agreements going forward. And we'll just have to see how that proceeds. Obviously, it
componenttext: I'll turn it over to Marta to comment on projected labor inflation. The entire industry, as you know, is engaged in collective bargaining over the terms of industry-wide agreements going forward. And we'll just have to see how that proceeds. Obviously, it's a protracted negotiation; it always is, particularly in an election year, though you tend to see that even more protracted than usual. Marta, what are you seeing in terms of the labor inflation down the road?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for this year 2016, we've guided to overall comp and benefits inflation, labor inflation of 3.5%. And that's a blend of wage inflation and medical inflation, which has been running quite high this year. For next year, it's still too soon to give a numb
componenttext: So for this year 2016, we've guided to overall comp and benefits inflation, labor inflation of 3.5%. And that's a blend of wage inflation and medical inflation, which has been running quite high this year. For next year, it's still too soon to give a number, but we'll try to clarify that for you on the January call.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Vernon with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Vernon with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marta and Jim, I just wanted to try and get a sense for kind of what's between where we are today at a $200 million annual run rate of productivity and the $600 million that you've got in your longer-term plan. I think I'm hearing you say, Marta, that exp
componenttext: Marta and Jim, I just wanted to try and get a sense for kind of what's between where we are today at a $200 million annual run rate of productivity and the $600 million that you've got in your longer-term plan. I think I'm hearing you say, Marta, that expenses are going to be kind of flat to maybe sequentially up a little bit here in the back half. I'm just trying to get an understanding of what is it that is between us and that higher productivity number. Is it capital investment, system investments, labor? And then maybe as a follow-up, are you thinking at all about maybe some more extensive co-production with CSX in some of the lower-density markets like coal, whether it's at the terminals or in the actual coal lines up in the coal fields themselves?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 6 months into a 5-year plan, we've made substantial progress on productivity, and we're sticking to our $200 million projected annual savings this year, at least $200 million. So we're well on our way to the $650 million by 2020. As you know, the compo
componenttext: So 6 months into a 5-year plan, we've made substantial progress on productivity, and we're sticking to our $200 million projected annual savings this year, at least $200 million. So we're well on our way to the $650 million by 2020. As you know, the components of that $650 million are heavily weighted to compensation and benefit savings, and that's a variety of elements. We have additional room to run in terms of fuel consumption improvements, but that's part of the longer-range plan. We'll continue to whittle away at locomotive maintenance costs. That's another component of the plan. And reduced equipment cost is a fourth element where we still have opportunity. Now in terms of coproduction, anywhere it makes sense for us to share assets with others operationally, we will certainly be open to doing so. That's a way to improve asset utilization for both parties.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But maybe just as a follow-up to that. Like as you think about going from that $200 million to, say, $400 million or whatever it's going to be on labor and compensation, how important is volume inflection to getting to that number? I mean, can you -- is t
componenttext: But maybe just as a follow-up to that. Like as you think about going from that $200 million to, say, $400 million or whatever it's going to be on labor and compensation, how important is volume inflection to getting to that number? I mean, can you -- is there something you're going to do operationally or investment-wise that's going to allow you to then kind of run that much more productively in a year or 2? Like I'm just trying to get a sense for kind of what the keys are to unlock that additional benefit. And I know it's an annual process where you're looking at ways to pull cost out. But is there anything that you can point to that says when we get here, this is going to help us run a lot more productively?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, volume helps productivity. There's no doubt about it because of the incremental operating leverage inherent in the business. But the key to the plan is flexibility. And we believe that we can achieve these levels of productivity going for
componenttext: Well, certainly, volume helps productivity. There's no doubt about it because of the incremental operating leverage inherent in the business. But the key to the plan is flexibility. And we believe that we can achieve these levels of productivity going forward, and we recognize the plan as dynamic. Volume conditions are changeable, and we'll make adjustments as necessary. If required, we'll go after deeper structural costs to achieve our goals.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Kauffman with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Kauffman with Buckingham Research.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now a lot of my questions have been asked, so let me just throw out a quick one. If I back out the fuel impact, it looks like revenue per unit was just a little bit less than flat. Can you break out the mix versus pricing component of that?
componenttext: Now a lot of my questions have been asked, so let me just throw out a quick one. If I back out the fuel impact, it looks like revenue per unit was just a little bit less than flat. Can you break out the mix versus pricing component of that?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is all mix, Jeff. If you take a look at the mix effect within coal, our export volumes trended more towards thermal coal than metallurgical coal if you take a look within intermodal. And as we've talked about, domestic volumes were pressured. The TCS r
componenttext: It is all mix, Jeff. If you take a look at the mix effect within coal, our export volumes trended more towards thermal coal than metallurgical coal if you take a look within intermodal. And as we've talked about, domestic volumes were pressured. The TCS restructuring impacted RPU, and international business has a lower RPU than us. And then if you take a deeper dive into our merchandise market and you can see declines in frac sand and crude oil pressuring overall RPU. So it was slightly down ex fuel, but it was all mix impact.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. If I back out the mix, what does core pricing look like, say, this quarter and relative to last quarter?
componenttext: All right. If I back out the mix, what does core pricing look like, say, this quarter and relative to last quarter?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's up this quarter over last quarter, and it's up over the same quarter last year, and it's up over rail inflation.
componenttext: It's up this quarter over last quarter, and it's up over the same quarter last year, and it's up over rail inflation.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Walter Spracklin with RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Walter Spracklin with RBC.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to touch on a little bit broader topic of new technology that you might have coming down the pipe. I know in the past, technological innovation like distributive powers led you to increase train lengths, and some of the trip optimizer software
componenttext: Just wanted to touch on a little bit broader topic of new technology that you might have coming down the pipe. I know in the past, technological innovation like distributive powers led you to increase train lengths, and some of the trip optimizer software has given you some pretty interesting fuel improvements. I guess, the first part of that question, are we pretty much done now? I know you've talked a bit about train lengths and how there is still a little bit of opportunity. But it sounds like it's more product driven rather than technological driven. Just correct me if I'm wrong there. And the second part, is there anything, perhaps for Mike -- Mike, when you look down the pipe, is there anything that gets you excited in terms of technological improvements that could lead to some further cost savings? I know within trucking, I mean, we're going as far as talking about autonomous trucks. Could we eventually see 1-person crews, that kind of thing? Just love to get your thoughts on that.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, on the run rate of the things you talked about, which is DP and the fuel efficiency technology we're using, we still have run rate to go there, and we still continue to implement it across the railroads, and we still have some opportunities going fo
componenttext: Well, on the run rate of the things you talked about, which is DP and the fuel efficiency technology we're using, we still have run rate to go there, and we still continue to implement it across the railroads, and we still have some opportunities going forward. And as Jim noted on the fuel efficiency, as part of our plan, that's a part of it. So yes, we feel we have opportunity there. On the technology side, I don't see that there's any one big thing that we're kind of hanging our hat on. But I will tell you that we have technology embedded throughout our organizations on making us better. Whether it's using alerts or using mobile platforms for the supervisors out in the field, things like that, we just continue to utilize technology throughout our operational organization to make us safer and more efficient.

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on 1-person crews?
componenttext: And on 1-person crews?

headline: Norfolk Southern Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a big industry initiative, and there's going to have to be a lot with the regulatory side there as well. Of course, we've got a lot of 1 person crews at our railroad now, whether it's pusher, whether it's remote control. But we work with the regula
componenttext: That's a big industry initiative, and there's going to have to be a lot with the regulatory side there as well. Of course, we've got a lot of 1 person crews at our railroad now, whether it's pusher, whether it's remote control. But we work with the regulators on what are the opportunities there going forward in the industry.
